ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The professor did less teaching and more guiding--most of the class time was taken up with student presentations based on the readings, so often we had minimal understanding of the topics we were discussing and we would have appreciated more of an introduction from the professor. He did try to guide the discussion but did not always bring clarity to the topics and I felt that we gained a very superficial knowledge of all of it. I'm not sure if prerequisites would have helped or if a different teaching format would have helped more. But I can tell that the topics covered in this course will be essential to understand in my professional career.

Readings and topics were great, although the style of lecture and material presentation could stand to vary a bit more. A field trip would be terrific, as would other events to make the class more dynamic. The NRDC presentation was fantastic and more emphasis on integrating readings and topics with current events and timely coastal issues would make this class really sparkle.

- Professor did not provide adequate guidance through what was often murky and convoluted intellectual material. Clear organization of ideas was lacking.- Readings were lengthy, digressive, tedious and often outdated. The course reading material needs to be updated to more recent discussions on ocean and coastal maters (of course, keeping in mind important historical contexts), and reading that is hopefully succinct and effective.- Class time was not conducive to a dynamic learning environment. Student presentations took up most class time- student presentations were not always the most conducive to through yet targeted discussion of key material.- Guidance questions given before the start of each class were a promising start to a directed discussion, but questions were not specifically addressed during class time. These focus questions might be a good start to a more specific organizational scheme for the class.
Rick is an amazing and interesting person. I really enjoyed hearing his stories and being able to learn from his experiences.
The course topics were both comprehensive and very current.
The topics covered.

The best thing about this course is that there is a final paper rather than a final exam, and students have a lot of flexibility to choose a paper topic that fits their interest. The course text book gives a great overview of the week's material. The guest speakers from NRDC were excellent!
The discussions, when they occurred. A small class with a committed and engaged teacher, we could really dig into issues and debate topics.
The flexibility of the professor to listen to student concerns and ideas, and willingness to work with student interests.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: There was almost too much reading, and I found it nearly impossible to read all of the material presented each week and found myself skimming most of it without really understanding.
None.
The format of class (basically 3 hours of student presentations, with minimal input from professor).
The weekly reading load was a bit too much some weeks, especially when the material is dense.

Mostly mentioned above but bears repeating: class could be more dynamic, with different speakers, presentation styles, and field trip like events. Connecting topics covered in class to events occurring outside of class would be valuable (just as you did with the NRDC presentation).
see question 11

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: No TA
Prompt and insightful.
He made himself very available and was flexible and helpful.
Instructor was very available and such a great resource. I got my summer internship, at CEQ, through his suggestion!
no TA

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It builds upon my academic background in marine biology and will augment my skill sets for professional work in the field of marine policy and governance.
I'm from the coast and I want to work on coastal issues. This class was my introduction to the topic and I think its lessons will prove more and more useful as time goes on.

I wish to be effective in coastal and ocean conservation. I sought to learn the recent historical and present policy and political landscape of these issues, with the intention of becoming a more effective ocean advocate.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get some insight into the policy making process
Out of interest and in preparation for professional work
I wanted to learn about coastal issues, which are rarely taught at FES.

Personal interest in marine and coastal issues. However, it would be helpful if the instructor explained the structure of the course more thoroughly at the beginning of the semester. I was surprised by how much time was spent discussing policy concepts.
see question 15

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
Above and beyond.
No, but I think it can be improved to become a great course.

The course material was interesting, and I would absolutely like to take another course from Professor Burroughs again! However, I personally do not like discussion-style courses because I think that they are seldom effective in practice.

Yes, largely I think so. I have to confess that I didn't finish all the readings all the time, but I hope to go back over what we covered this summer and really commit it to memory. Posting lecture slides would be really useful, actually.
no.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes, much more in fact, in a positive way.
I didn't get as strong of an understanding of coastal issues and policies as I would have liked.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I found it helpful to coordinate presentations as a groupp, especiially when the presentations were cohesive as opposed to separate by students.
We didn't take full advantage of the group work because most people divided the group work (presentations) up and just did their own part separately.

Students gave class presentations on assigned readings at least twice during the semester. I sought to collaborate with my fellow student presenters, in hopes of designing class presentations that were both effective at communicating important material, and enjoyable. These exercises were advantageous- one often learns as much working with team mates as one does working individually.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Try to do the readings because it will make the presentations go much more smoothly.
Start thinking about the final paper topic early.

Do the readings, or you will get little out of the class. Encourage the professor to do a lecture at the beginning of class before launching into student presentations (or eliminate these altogether). The most interesting part of class was the guest lecture--encourage more of these.
Push your fellow students to engage with the subject matter critically. Class was most fun when we were arguing with professor Burroughs or ourselves.
Unless the course is significantly altered, I would not retake the course, and only skim some of the reading material.
